e4: A change to the new policy without bias is highly recommended, considering it promotes greater ethical financial reporting and protects the firm from legal liabilities. Addressing the CFO's concern about retail investors being at a disadvantage, education regarding changes can be implemented alongside the adoption of new policy, ensuring they understand its benefits in long-term stability.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should provide full transparency, be truthful in nature, comply with regulations to avoid legal issues or penalties for negligent practices, promote accurate disclosure of financial information to protect investor confidence, and encourage openness about past financial performance to build trust among retail investors along with large sophisticated institutional investors. Fairly representing financial health through consistent accounting standards provides honesty and equality to all market participants in forming their investment judgments.
e6: To understand ABC company's current financial report policy, it is suggested to pose several follow-up questions. First, request thorough information from management on specific reasons and duration behind adopting this consistent underreporting of earnings per share. Secondly, gather evidence corroborating the consistency of a 50 cents bias adjustment made by sophisticated and retail investors. Additionally, delve deeper into the specific regulatory considerations preventing legal action against the firm despite unbiased reporting practice, and request concrete details on the legal counsel's perspective. Furthermore, inquire about the board's risk management policy towards market exposure under both current and proposed new no-bias financial report policy.
